Award.AwardTitle: Oxidation Processes in Forest Canopies and Biosphere-Atmosphere Exchange of Nitrogen Oxides
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims at an improved understanding of atmospheric oxidation processes, using the Sacramento urban plume and its interactions with the forest ecosystems of the mid-elevation Sierra Nevada Mountains as a case study, and an improved understanding of the mechanisms of atmosphere-biosphere exchange of nitrogen occurring in those forests. Specific tasks include: 1) development and subsequent field deployment and evaluation of a new instrument for detection of HONO (nitrous acid); 2) two four-month field campaigns including measurements of concentrations of NO (nitric oxide), NO2 (nitrogen dioxide), HONO, NO3 (nitrate radical), N2O5 (dinitrogen pentoxide), the sum of PNs (acyl peroxynitrates), the sum of ANs (alkyl nitrates), HNO3 (nitric acid), and NOy (total reactive nitrogen), some at more than one height in the forest canopy, along with fluxes of most of these species, and 3) development of new models and analyses to interpret the measurements obtained in the field studies, with the aim of understanding the role of atmospheric nitrogen oxides in regulating the rates of oxidative photochemistry, chemistry in the forest canopy, and the mechanisms of atmosphere-biosphere exchange of nitrogen.
The ultimate goal of the project is to better understand the influence of nitrogen oxide emissions on air pollution, climate, and ecosystem processes. Other broader impacts include 1) training of women and minority graduate students; 2) participation of undergraduates in research; and 3) continued encouragement of graduate student volunteer work in K-8 schools. The project is highly collaborative and will bring Berkeley graduate students into contact with students from several other institutions during the field studies. The results and methodology will be included in an introductory chemistry class and new materials will be prepared for use in the physical chemistry laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Oxidation Processes in Forest Canopies and Biosphere-Atmosphere Exchange of Nitrogen Oxides

Project Outcomes for the general Public

Nitrogen oxides chemicals regulate the rate of many atmospheric process. In particular, they are key species in the production of surface O3 which is both a hazard to human and animal health and the cause for billions of dollars of economic losses associated with damage to crops and livestock. In this project we collected new observations of nitrogen oxides and invented new methods for measuring nitrogen oxides. We made these observations downwind of a small city—Sacramento CA and under controlled laboratory conditions. The research resulted in more than 18 publications in the technical literature. Key findings are

1) confirmation that the class of molecules that are organic nitrates are more important to the chemistry of the atmosphere than is represented in the current generation of air pollution models.

2) evaluation of the effectiveness of air pollution control measures in the Sacramento metropolitan area showing that they have dramatically reduced the frequency of violations and indicating that if current trends continue violations will completely end within 10 years. The methods we developed for this analysis are applicable to evaluating air quality improvements (or lack thereof) in a variety of locations.

3) measurements that provide insight—and specific numbers for use in detailed numerical model—into how aerosol forms when urban emissions mix with emissions of the surrounding forests.

 

In addition to these direct research products, the project contributed to the education and professional development of graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and undergraduates who participated in the research (many with separate fellowships that supported the bulk of their salary). Some of these students have now moved on to permanent careers in academia, government service and the private sector. Others are continuing the education or professional development as postdoctoral fellows at institutions including MIT, NOAA, US EPA, Colorado State University, Reed College, Lawrence Berkeley national laboratory, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, and at the Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology.
